sentence: Stocks were treading water Tuesday with very slim gains despite better than expected earnings results from retailing giants Macy's ( M ) and Dow component Home Depot ( HD ).

Economic data today offered little direction, although a bigger than expected drop in consumer confidence erased some of the market's earlier gains despite most again blaming the decline on severe winter weather.

But while market action today has not been very inspiring, profit-taking pressure is negligible ahead of what is expected to be market-friendly testimony from Fed Chair Janet Yellen to the Senate Banking Committee on Thursday.
The last time Yellen spoke before Congress, her dovish comments drove equities sharply higher.
In today's economic data, housing prices continue to appreciate although the pace of rising prices was showing signs of losing momentum.
The Federal Housing Finance Agency reported a 0.8% gain in its house price index for December calling the recent gain "considerable" but "more modest" than in prior quarters.
The Case Shiller index said essentially the same thing with the home price index also climbing 0.8% from +0.9% the month prior and beating estimates for a modest 0.6% increase.

The next round of data had elements of weather conditions as both consumer confidence and the Richmond Fed index declined in February, the latter plummeting to -6.0 from +12.0 in January and well below estimates for a decline to +0.3.
The Conference Board said its consumer confidence index fell to 78.1 versus the consensus estimate of 80.0 and down from the revised 79.4 in January.
European markets all closed lower, unable to recover off overnight lows as concerns about Chinese economic growth and a possible EU rate cut weigh on equities.
Crude oil was down $1.29 to $101.53 per barrel.
Natural gas was up $0.10 to $4.72 per 1 million BTU.
Gold was up $3.20 $1,341.20 an ounce, while silver was down $0.10 to $21.99 an ounce.
Copper was down $0.02 to $3.23 per pound.
Among energy ETFs, the United States Oil Fund was down 1.05% to $36.40 with the United States Natural Gas Fund was down 0.27% to $26.05.
Amongst precious-metal funds, the Market Vectors Gold Miners ETF was down 0.66% to 26.57 while SPDR Gold Shares was up 0.29% to $129.37.
The iShares Silver Trust was down 0.32% to $21.11.

Here's where the markets stand at mid-day:

(+) INFI (+13.73%) Reported a FY13 net loss of $2.64 per common share versus consensus estimates of a loss of $2.75 per share

(+) ZU (+41.92%) Reported much better than expected Q4 results

(-) GTLS (-9.56%) Reported mixed financial results for Q4 that fell short of analysts' expectations.
(-) RP (-22.68%) Downgraded to Sector Perform from Outperform at RBC after the company reported mixed Q4 results.
